source.name: City of Pittsburgh Department of Public Works
source.notes: Based on official Pittsburgh DPW Blue Bin Program guidelines. ALL lids and caps must be removed and trashed (unusual rule). Max 3-gallon containers for plastic/glass. Blue container required.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: REMOVE all plastic and metal lids and caps — throw lids in TRASH
Place bottle in blue recycling bin
Container must be 3 gallons or less
notes: Pittsburgh requires ALL lids and caps to be removed and trashed — this is unique
Max container size: 3 gallons
Items must be loose in the bin — no plastic bags
Blue bin max 35 gallons
commonMistakes: Don't leave lids or caps on — remove and TRASH them
Don't bag recyclables in plastic bags
Don't include containers larger than 3 gallons

materials.name: Plastic jugs
instructions: REMOVE all lids and caps — throw in TRASH
notes: All lids must be removed and trashed
commonMistakes: Don't leave caps on
Containers over 3 gallons are not accepted

materials.name: Plastic jars
instructions: REMOVE lid — throw lid in TRASH
notes: All lids must be removed and trashed
commonMistakes: Don't leave lid on

materials.name: Plastic tubs
instructions: REMOVE lid — throw lid in TRASH
notes: All lids must be removed and trashed
commonMistakes: Don't leave lid on
Don't include with food residue

materials.name: Glass bottles
instructions: REMOVE all lids and caps — throw in TRASH
notes: Pittsburgh requires removing ALL lids and caps from glass bottles — unique rule
Max 3-gallon containers
commonMistakes: Don't leave caps or lids on — remove and TRASH them
Don't include broken glass

materials.name: Glass jars
instructions: REMOVE metal lid — throw lid in TRASH
notes: All lids must be removed and trashed — even metal ones
commonMistakes: Don't leave metal or plastic lids on

materials.name: Glass jugs
notes: Max 3-gallon containers
commonMistakes: Don't leave cap on

materials.name: Aluminum cans
notes: Aluminum cans do not typically have removable lids
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with liquid

materials.name: Steel / tin cans
instructions: REMOVE lid if detached — throw loose lids in TRASH
notes: If the lid is still attached by a hinge, leave it; if fully detached, trash it
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still in them

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Place in or beside blue recycling bin
notes: Cardboard is one of the accepted categories
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard soaked with grease
Don't leave unflattened

materials.name: Paperboard / thin cardboard
notes: Part of the mixed paper/cardboard category
commonMistakes: Don't include if heavily soiled

materials.name: Office paper
notes: Part of mixed paper category
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels or tissues

materials.name: Newspapers
notes: Part of mixed paper category
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic bags

materials.name: Magazines and catalogs
notes: Glossy paper and staples are fine
commonMistakes: Don't remove staples

materials.name: Books
instructions: Otherwise place in blue recycling bin
notes: Part of mixed paper category — books, catalogs, phone books all accepted
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in trash

materials.name: Junk mail and envelopes
notes: Part of mixed paper category
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic bags

materials.name: Lids and caps (all types)
instructions: REMOVE all lids and caps from recyclable containers
Throw ALL lids and caps in the TRASH
This includes plastic caps, metal lids, and screw caps
notes: Pittsburgh has a unique rule: ALL lids and caps must be removed and trashed
This applies to plastic, metal, and all other lid types
Most other cities allow caps to stay on — Pittsburgh does not
commonMistakes: Don't leave lids on recyclable containers
Don't try to recycle lids separately

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: Take clean dry bags to grocery store drop-off bins
Do NOT use to bag recyclables — items must be LOOSE
notes: Never bag recyclables in plastic bags
Pittsburgh requires all recyclables to be loose in the blue bin
commonMistakes: Never bag recyclables in plastic bags
Items must be loose in the bin

materials.name: Styrofoam / polystyrene
notes: Styrofoam is not recyclable curbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Food waste
instructions: Pittsburgh does not have curbside composting
notes: No curbside composting program
commonMistakes: Don't put food in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Fruit and fruit scraps
notes: No curbside composting in Pittsburgh
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Vegetables and vegetable scraps
notes: No curbside composting
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Bag and place in regular trash
notes: No curbside composting
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Coffee grounds / tea bags
notes: No curbside composting; consider home composting
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Food portion goes in regular trash
Rinse and recycle the container — remove lid first
notes: Remember to remove and trash the lid
commonMistakes: Don't recycle containers with food in them
Don't forget to remove lid

materials.name: Pizza box (clean)
instructions: Clean pizza boxes: place in blue recycling bin
Tear off clean portions; trash greasy parts
notes: Clean cardboard is recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include heavily greased portions

materials.name: Pizza box (greasy)
instructions: Greasy portions go in regular trash
notes: Grease contaminates paper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy cardboard in the blue bin

materials.name: Aerosol cans (empty)
instructions: REMOVE cap — throw cap in TRASH
notes: Remove the plastic overcap before recycling
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized
Don't forget to remove and trash the cap

materials.name: Aluminum foil (clean)
notes: Must be clean
commonMistakes: Don't recycle heavily soiled foil

materials.name: Aluminum trays
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include heavily soiled trays

materials.name: Beverage cartons
instructions: REMOVE cap if present — throw cap in TRASH
notes: Remember to remove any caps
commonMistakes: Don't leave caps on

materials.name: Candy wrapper
notes: Multi-layer film packaging cannot be recycled
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Chip bag / snack bag
notes: Metallized plastic cannot be recycled
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Bubble wrap / packing materials
notes: Film plastics not accepted in curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Window glass / mirrors
notes: Different glass composition than bottles/jars
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Ceramics / pottery
notes: Ceramics contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't mix with glass recyclables

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Do NOT put in any curbside container
Take to an Allegheny County drop-off event or facility
Or take to Best Buy or Staples
notes: Pittsburgh does not accept electronics in curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in trash or recycling
Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do NOT put in any curbside container
Take to an Allegheny County household hazardous waste event
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries
notes: Batteries can cause fires in garbage trucks
commonMistakes: Don't throw batteries in trash or recycling

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to Allegheny County household hazardous waste event
Latex paint: dry out with kitty litter then trash
Oil-based: must go to hazardous waste
notes: Check Allegheny County website for drop-off events
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain

materials.name: Chemicals and cleaners
instructions: Take to Allegheny County household hazardous waste event
notes: Never put chemicals in regular trash or recycling
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to a pharmacy drug take-back location
Pittsburgh police stations may host take-back events
If no drop-off: mix with coffee grounds, seal, and trash
notes: Never flush medications
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications

materials.name: CFL and fluorescent bulbs
instructions: Take to Home Depot, Lowe's, or hazardous waste event
notes: Mercury is hazardous
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash or recycling
Don't break them

materials.name: LED and incandescent bulbs
instructions: Wrap and place in regular trash
notes: Not hazardous but not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with CFL which is hazardous

materials.name: Diapers
instructions: Bag and place in regular trash
notes: Not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Receipts
notes: Cannot be recycled
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in regular trash
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't flush cat litter

materials.name: Clothing / textiles
instructions: Donate to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or local charities
Worn-out textiles still accepted at donation bins
notes: Don't put in any curbside container
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in trash if donatable

materials.name: Furniture / large items
instructions: Schedule bulk pickup through Pittsburgh DPW
notes: Pittsburgh offers bulk item pickup
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Appliances
instructions: Remove doors from refrigerators for safety
notes: Appliances contain recyclable metals
commonMistakes: Don't put in regular trash

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Take to auto parts store or hazardous waste event
notes: Most auto parts stores accept oil for free
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Take to hazardous waste collection event
Never put in any curbside container
notes: Pressurized containers are fire risks
commonMistakes: Never puncture
Never put in trash

materials.name: Smartphone / cell phone
instructions: Factory reset and wipe personal data
Take to Best Buy for free recycling
notes: Contains valuable materials; battery fire risk in trash
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe personal data
Don't put in regular trash

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Most shops accept old tires when buying new
notes: Not accepted in curbside containers
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally

materials.name: Hangers
notes: Wire hangers tangle in recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Wax paper / parchment paper
notes: Coating prevents recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Plastic straws and utensils
notes: Too small for recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Makeup / cosmetics containers
instructions: Clean plastic jars/tubs may go in blue bin (remove lid)
notes: Remember to remove and trash lids even on cosmetic containers going in recycling
commonMistakes: Don't forget the lid rule applies to cosmetic containers too

materials.name: Wrapping paper
instructions: Plain uncoated paper: blue recycling bin
notes: Most wrapping paper has coatings preventing recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put metallic or glittery paper in recycling

materials.name: Cooking oil / grease
instructions: Place sealed container in regular trash
notes: Never pour oil down the drain
commonMistakes: Don't pour down sink or storm drains

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Place in yard waste bags or bundle branches
Set out for separate yard waste collection
notes: Not accepted in blue recycling bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Chargers and cables
instructions: Take to Best Buy or e-waste collection event
Do NOT put in blue recycling bin
notes: Cables tangle in recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put cables in recycling

materials.name: Ink / toner cartridges
instructions: Return to Staples or Office Depot
notes: Some stores give credit for returns
commonMistakes: Don't throw in regular trash

materials.name: Toothbrush
notes: Mixed plastic materials; not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling bin

materials.name: Shredded paper
notes: Shredded paper falls through recycling screens
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper in the blue bin

recycle: Plastic bottles, jugs, jars, and tubs (3 gallons or less) — REMOVE ALL LIDS
Glass bottles, jugs, and jars (3 gallons or less) — REMOVE ALL LIDS
Mixed paper — office paper, newspapers, magazines, books, catalogs, junk mail, phone books, paperboard
trash: ALL lids and caps (plastic and metal)

recycle: Lids and caps of any kind — all must be removed and trashed

tips: Pittsburgh uses BLUE bins/containers for recycling — weekly collection
CRITICAL: Remove ALL plastic and metal lids and caps and throw them in the TRASH — this is unique to Pittsburgh
Max container size for plastic and glass: 3 gallons
All items must be LOOSE in the blue bin — no plastic bags
Blue recycling container must be max 35 gallons; any container marked 'recycling' works if you don't have the official blue bin
Set out: no sooner than 6 PM the day before, no later than 6 AM on collection day
Remove bins by 10 PM on collection day
Program serves single-family homes and buildings with 5 or fewer units
No curbside composting — food waste goes in regular trash
Recycling is required for all Pittsburgh residents
Contact Pittsburgh DPW for collection schedules and bulk pickup
